awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Effects of mitohormesis on reproduction and longevity
awd_abstract_narration:
A central tenet of biology is that allocation to reproduction trades off against allocation to processes that enhance longevity. Reproduction takes energy and energy production induces the release of damaging reactive oxygen species (ROS) within the mitochondria. ROS are normal byproducts of cellular respiration that can damage cells and as a result, reduce longevity. Yet, several studies have now shown that damage from ROS is typically unchanged or even reduced in animals that reproduce compared to those that don't.  In addition, new theory suggests that low levels of exposure to ROS, as occurs during reproduction, not only lowers damage from ROS but may also protect cells from the cellular damage that contributes to aging. The goals of this project are to test if the ROS generated during reproduction protects against future ROS damage, determine how ROS damage and the performance of mitochondria change with reproductive experience and age, and characterize the relationship between reproductive experience and longevity in the house mouse.  Research on the interaction between mitochondrial function, reproduction, and longevity will be used as a platform for education and the improvement of science literacy in the state of Alabama. In collaboration of with local biology teachers, lesson plans with labs will be developed for 7th and 9th graders. These lessons will feature the proposed research on mitochondria and aging and will be submitted to the Alabama State Board of Education for adoption in every 7th and 9th grade biology classroom in Alabama. In addition, Auburn graduate students will be challenged to commit to regular participation in outreach in a graduate-level seminar "mitochondria and energetics". Students will prepare and present a lesson for Auburn University's Get Under the Surface program that invites 5th grade students and their parents to campus to participate in an interactive laboratory. 

The goals of this CAREER project are to 1) test whether reproduction protects against future oxidative damage and 2) to determine if mitochondrial function and the cellular response to an induced oxidative stressor change with age in a continuously breeding species, the house mouse (Mus musculus). Given the potentially protective effects that reproduction has on processes that induce aging, a third goal of this project is 3) to evaluate the interaction between reproduction and longevity in female mice by comparing age at death in females that have bred few times verses those that have bred many times. Several cutting-edge techniques will be employed in this investigation including measurements of ROS production from mitochondria and oxidative damage in organs that commonly decline during senescence. In addition, respiratory control ratio, electron chain complex activity, mitochondrial biogenesis, abundance of uncoupling proteins and levels of endogenous antioxidants will be evaluated. The impact of treatment on insulin-like growth factor-1 and telomere length will also be evaluated as indicators of the impact of treatment on aging. This investigation will provide a detailed assessment of the role that reproduction plays in the accumulation of ROS and in resistance to stressors that hasten aging. Unlike many studies that have searched for a mechanistic basis for the tradeoff between reproduction and longevity, this study will ask whether such a tradeoff really exists. Whether this study supports or refutes the idea that ROS produced during reproduction contributes to age, the project will transform the study of life-history evolution, and the outcome will be a better understanding of the mechanistic relationship between aging and reproduction.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching aim of this project was to improve our understanding of the role of mitochondrial function and reactive oxygen species (ROS) exposure in reproduction and longevity and to train high school students in the biology of mitochondria and animal energetics. 

Mitochondrial response to ROS

Before our research, it was generally assumed within the ecophysiology community that oxidative damage was persistent and necessarily negatively impacted mitochondrial performance. Exposing mice to modest dose ROS generating radiation (x-ray) and collecting samples 1h, 1d, 4d, 7d, and 10d post-exposure, we found that oxidative damage to lipids and proteins increased and then returned to control levels. Mitochondrial respiratory function dropped and returned to control levels, and relative activity of complexes I, III, and IV increased and remained high 10d after exposure. These results show that an oxidative event need not have lasting, detrimental impacts on mitochondrial performance and may improve mitochondrial performance.

Life events, mitochondrial function, and oxidative stress.  

We worked with another species, Tigriopus copepods, where we could evaluate the life-long impacts of oxidant exposure. We exposed virgin female copepods to ROS generating UV-light for 0h, 1h, or 3h. We found copepods exposed to UV had a larger first clutch but shorter lifespan than unexposed copepods. To elucidate how copepods improve their performance after exposure to UV, we quantified metabolic rate and mitochondrial morphology in muscle cells following 0, 3, and 6h UV exposure. We found that inner mitochondrial membrane (IMM) density was greater with UV exposure. Metabolic rate was maintained after 3h of UV but decreased following 6h. These observations demonstrate that the high density of IMM likely maintains metabolic rate under exposure to an oxidative stressor but fails to do so when exposure is high. 

To determine how stress during reproduction alters the maternal reproductive-longevity tradeoff and future fitness in offspring, we evaluated how a stressor during reproduction impacts maternal and offspring mitochondria. We found that mothers exposed to stress hormone (CORT) had a lower litter mass at weaning but did not impact maternal mitochondrial respiration or oxidative stress. The offspring of stressed mothers had improved mitochondrial function and reduced oxidative stress. These findings suggest that elevated maternal CORT may signal early-life adversity and prepare the offspring with a predictive, adaptive response for future stressors. Under the conditions of this study, stress did not impact the reproduction-longevity tradeoff.

Next, we evaluated how a mitohormetic event before reproduction impacted a mother's reproductive performance and the performance of her mitochondria. Female mice were allowed to run (stimulating mitochondrial hormesis) or not for a month before mating to simulate mitohormesis. Females that ran gave birth to more young and weaned a heavier litter, indicating that physical activity positively affected energy allocated to reproduction. Mice that ran also displayed higher mitochondrial respiration and biogenesis after weaning. 

We evaluated the effect of reproduction on mitochondrial DNA mutations (mtDNA) and mitochondrial respiration in old house mice (1.3y) that had lived in our seminatural enclosures. We found the replication error was associated with more mtDNA than oxidative damage in the liver, but the opposite was true for the brain. The number of oxidative damage and replication error mutations in the skeletal muscle was similar. In the brain, skeletal muscle, and liver, reproductive mice had few replication error mutations than non-reproductive mice but no difference in oxidative damage mutations. Further, the number of mtDNA mutations associated with replication error was equal to or greater than oxidative damage for skeletal muscle and liver, respectively, and only significantly lower than oxidative damage mutations in the brain, highlighting the importance of replication error to mtDNA damage across tissues. Interestingly, despite variation in the number of mtDNA mutations, mitochondrial respiratory function and oxidative damage to the liver, muscle, and brain were similar between reproductive and non-reproductive females. These values were not different from mice of the same age and older mice (2.3y) housed under the standard laboratory conditions, suggesting the overall mitochondrial oxygen use may be resilient to aging and the environment in house mice. Importantly, oxidative stress does not appear to be an important contributor to mitochondrial respiratory decline and the reproductive-longevity tradeoff in house mice.

Broader Impacts

In collaboration with two Alabama high school teachers, we developed four laboratories related to energy expenditure and mitochondria for the Alabama Science in Motion program. These labs included a scientific literacy reading, experiment procedures, and a video for teachers on how to perform the experiment. Eighteen local teachers were brought to the Auburn University campus and trained on how to apply the lab in the classroom. These teachers then used the labs in the classroom during the two subsequent semesters, and pre- and post-lab assessments were given to the students. The findings suggest these labs improved students understanding of mitochondria and energetics.
